mods:titleInfo.mods:title: FBI arrests Japanese civilians on Terminal Island (Calif.)

mods:mods.mods:note: FBI agents arrest Japanese males, including many community and religious leaders, in the first round of forced evacuations from Terminal Island following the Japanese attack on Pearl Habor

Terminal Island, an artificial island in the Los Angeles Harbor and Long Beach Harbor, was the American base of the Japanese fishing industry until residents were forcefully arrested or evacuated between 1941 and 1942

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reenactment of the 1769 Gaspar de Portolá expedition

mods:mods.mods:note: The reenactment of the 1769 Gaspar de Portolá expedition reaches Los Angeles City Hall, where musicians and costumed actors are gathered

Gaspar de Portolá was appointed Governor of Las Californias from 1768-1770. During that time, he expelled the Jesuits from Baja California and led expeditions by land and sea to settle colonies on the California coast

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Home in Chavez Ravine, Los Angeles (Calif.)

mods:mods.mods:note: A family gathers on the porch of their home in Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles

Chavez Ravine residents were forced to relocate in the 1940s when the City voted to accept federal funding for new housing developments in the area. When these apartment projects failed several years later, the remaining residents of Chavez Ravine were removed by a controversial order of eminent domain to build Dodger Stadium

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sleepy Lagoon murder case acquittal

mods:mods.mods:note: Defendants in the Sleepy Lagoon murder case are reunited with friends and family in the Los Angeles Hall of Justice following their acquittal

After the murder and assault convictions of 17 Mexican American youths in the Sleepy Lagoon murder case, the Sleepy Lagoon Defense Committee advocated for the defendants until the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the convictions as a miscarriage of justice

mods:mods.mods:note: In a historical costume reenactment of a Gaspar de Portolá expedition, mounted Spaniards encounter North American Indian peoples outside of Los Angeles City Hall. Musicians and dancers are gathered in the background

Gaspar de Portolá was appointed Governor of Las Californias from 1768-1770. During that time, he expelled the Jesuits from Baja California and led expeditions by land and sea to settle colonies on the California coast

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Virginia Swanson Yamamoto in front of Terminal Island Baptist Church

mods:mods.mods:note: Virginia Swanson Yamamoto, wife of Reverend Kichitaro Yamamoto, stands outside the Terminal Island Baptist Church with a Japanese American child in her arms

Terminal Island Baptist Church assisted its congregation during the 48 hour evacuation period from Terminal Island by helping residents pack and sell their belongings, typing property inventories, and giving women and children a place to stay

mods:mods.mods:note: Street scene of the Mexican American community Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Home in Chavez Ravine, Los Angeles (Calif.)

mods:mods.mods:note: Women visit on the porch of a home in the Mexican American community of Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium. Photographed are Mercedes Avias, Rebecca Palacios, Eliza Baker, and the child Richie Baker

Chavez Ravine residents were forced to relocate in the 1940s when the City voted to accept federal funding for new housing developments in the area. When these apartment projects failed several years later, the remaining residents of Chavez Ravine were removed by a controversial order of eminent domain to build Dodger Stadium

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Sleepy Lagoon murder case acquittal

mods:mods.mods:note: Defendants in the Sleepy Lagoon murder trial are reunited with family and friends in the Los Angeles Hall of Justice following their acquittal

After the murder and assault convictions of 17 Mexican American youths in the Sleepy Lagoon murder case, the Sleepy Lagoon Defense Committee advocated for the defendants until the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the convictions as a miscarriage of justice

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Pan American Day celebration

mods:mods.mods:note: Photographed from left to right are Jorge Maroto, Manuel Aguilar, Mayor Fletcher Bowron, and Gabriela Mistral

Pan American Day was first celebrated on April 14, 1931 to commemorate the 1890 establishment of the Union of American Republics, later called the Pan American Union. This body subsequently evolved into the Organization of American States. Pan American Day is an international holiday that celebrates the cultures of North and South American nations and stresses inter-American goodwill

mods:name.mods:namePart: International Trade and Export Development Program (Organization of American States)

mods:mods.mods:note: A billboard announces the revival of Old Chinatown in Los Angeles, California

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Paul Robeson awaits testimony before the Committee of Un-American Activities

mods:mods.mods:note: Civil rights activist and accomplished actor and singer Paul Robeson awaits testimony before the Committee of Un-American Activities

An accomplished graduate of Rutgers University and Columbia Law School, Paul Robeson was a sucessful stage actor and civil rights activist in the 1940s when he was accused of disloyalty to the United States and was the subject of several invasive federal investigations

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reenactment of the 1769 Gaspar de Portolá expedition

mods:mods.mods:note: In a historical costume reenactment of a Gaspar de Portolá expedition, mounted Spaniards encounter North American Indian peoples outside of Los Angeles City Hall

Gaspar de Portolá was appointed Governor of Las Californias from 1768-1770. During that time, he expelled the Jesuits from Baja California and led expeditions by land and sea to settle colonies on the California coast

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Land use inspection in Chavez Ravine, Los Angeles (Calif.)

mods:mods.mods:note: John Carmona and Fred Ross inspect the Mexican American community of Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium, as two children look on

Chavez Ravine residents were forced to relocate in the 1940s when the City voted to accept federal funding for new housing developments in the area. When these apartment projects failed several years later, the remaining residents of Chavez Ravine were removed by a controversial order of eminent domain to build Dodger Stadium

mods:mods.mods:note: Defendants in the Sleepy Lagoon murder case reunite with friends and family in the Los Angeles Hall of Justice following their acquittal

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home in Chavez Ravine, Los Angeles (Calif.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A family gathers on the porch of their home in Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles

Chavez Ravine residents were forced to relocate in the 1940s when the City voted to accept federal funding for new housing developments in the area. When these apartment projects failed several years later, the remaining residents of Chavez Ravine were removed by a controversial order of eminent domain to build Dodger Stadium

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Home in Chavez Ravine, Los Angeles (Calif.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Women visit on the porch of a home in the Mexican American community of Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium. Photographed are Mercedes Avias, Rebecca Palacios, Eliza Baker, and the child Richie Baker

Chavez Ravine residents were forced to relocate in the 1940s when the City voted to accept federal funding for new housing developments in the area. When these apartment projects failed several years later, the remaining residents of Chavez Ravine were removed by a controversial order of eminent domain to build Dodger Stadium

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pan American Day celebration
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photographed from left to right are Jorge Maroto, Manuel Aguilar, Mayor Fletcher Bowron, and Gabriela Mistral

Pan American Day was first celebrated on April 14, 1931 to commemorate the 1890 establishment of the Union of American Republics, later called the Pan American Union. This body subsequently evolved into the Organization of American States. Pan American Day is an international holiday that celebrates the cultures of North and South American nations and stresses inter-American goodwill

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In a historical costume reenactment of a Gaspar de Portolá expedition, mounted Spaniards encounter North American Indian peoples outside of Los Angeles City Hall

Gaspar de Portolá was appointed Governor of Las Californias from 1768-1770. During that time, he expelled the Jesuits from Baja California and led expeditions by land and sea to settle colonies on the California coast

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Land use inspection in Chavez Ravine, Los Angeles (Calif.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: John Carmona and Fred Ross inspect the Mexican American community of Chavez Ravine, located near present day Elysian Park and Dodger Stadium, as two children look on

Chavez Ravine residents were forced to relocate in the 1940s when the City voted to accept federal funding for new housing developments in the area. When these apartment projects failed several years later, the remaining residents of Chavez Ravine were removed by a controversial order of eminent domain to build Dodger Stadium

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Robert Telles, age 19, reunites with family members Betty Telles and Josie Telles in the Los Angeles Hall of Justice following his acquittal in the Sleepy Lagoon murder case
